'''Calvin Leavy''' (April 20, 1940 – June 6, 2010) was an [[African American]] [[soul blues]] and [[electric blues]] singer and guitarist.<ref name="Arkansas"/><ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p173360/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Calvin Leavy |author= |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=November 16, 2011}}</ref> He had a [[hit single]] in 1970, when "Cummins Prison Farm" peaked at number 40 on the [[United States|US]] ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|R&B]] [[record chart|chart]], and stayed in the chart for five weeks.<ref name="Whitburn">{{cite book |title= Top R&B/Hip-Hop Singles: 1942-1995|last=Whitburn |first=Joel |authorlink=Joel Whitburn |year=1996 |publisher=Record Research |page=262}}</ref> More locally, it was number one on the chart of the [[Memphis, Tennessee]] based [[Radio broadcasting|radio station]], [[WDIA]].<ref name="Arkansas"/>

Later in his life, Leavy became the first person indicted under the 1988 Drug Kingpin Law, and he subsequently died in prison.<ref name="Arkansas"/>

==Biography==
'''Calvin James Leavy''' was born in Scott, [[Pulaski County, Arkansas]], [[United States]]. He was the youngest son of fifteen children, and started singing in his church choir.  By his adolescence, Leavy sang with various [[gospel music|gospel]] [[musical ensemble|ensembles]] in [[Little Rock, Arkansas|Little Rock]]. He formed the Leavy Brothers Band in 1954, and they were popular locally, before relocating to [[Fresno, California]]. By the end of 1968, they moved back to Little Rock, and played at local [[nightclub|clubs]].  Through this work, Leavy was offered recording time in E&M Studios in Little Rock.  As well as a [[cover version]] of "[[Tennessee Waltz]]", the group recorded the song "Cummins Prison Farm", which was written by Bill Cole.  Leavy used the prison experiences of one of his brothers to expand the lyrical content.<ref name="Arkansas">{{cite web |url=http://encyclopediaofarkansas.net/encyclopedia/entry-detail.aspx?entryID=6346 |title=Calvin James "Slim" Leavy (1940–2010) |author=Gwendolyn L. Shelton |date= |work= |publisher=Encyclopediaofarkansas.net |accessdate=November 16, 2011}}</ref>  It was originally issued on Soul Beat Records, and underwent subsequent national distribution via Blue Fox Records, that label's first release.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.45cat.com/record/100us9 |title=Record details |author= |date= |work= |publisher=45cat.com |accessdate=November 16, 2011}}</ref> "Cummins Prison Farm", reached number 40 on the  ''Billboard'' R&B chart.<ref name="Whitburn"/>  Recorded in one take, it was one of 27 blues based songs that reached the R&B chart in 1970.<ref name="Arkansas"/>

Leavy recorded further [[Single (music)|singles]] for Acquarian, Soul Beat, Downtown and Messenger Records.<ref name="Sunday">{{cite web |url=http://sundayblues.org/archives/tag/calvin-leavy |title=Big Road Blues |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Sundayblues.org |accessdate=November 16, 2011}}</ref>  These included "Nothing But Your Love", "Give Me a Love (That I Can Feel)" and "Goin’ to the Dogs Pt. 1". In addition, the band made some recordings for the Arkansas Bicentennial Blues Project, which were archived at the [[University of Arkansas at Little Rock]]. They also appeared in 1977 at the [[Memphis in May|Beale Street Music Festival]], before disbanding. Forming Calvin Leavy and the Professionals, he and his new outfit remained popular locally. They recorded "Is It Worth All (That I'm Going Through)", "Big Four", "What Kind of Love", "Free From Cummins Prison Farm", and the prophetic "If Life Last Luck Is Bound to Change". However, further national chart success eluded him.<ref name="Arkansas"/> Nevertheless, he maintained a strong fan base in the [[Southern United States|South]], and his records often appeared on local [[jukebox]]es.<ref name="Sunday"/>
[[File:CumminsUnitSignArk.jpg|thumb|right|[[Cummins Unit|Cummins Prison]], both the inspiration for Leavy's only national hit record, and his later  'residence']]
In 1991, Leavy was charged with making payments to an undercover police officer, and was convicted in July 1992, of multiple drug related offences.<ref name="Today">{{cite web |url=http://www.todaysthv.com/news/story.aspx?storyid=106121 |title=Calvin Leavy dies at 70 |author=Amanda Terrebonne |date=June 7, 2010 |work= |publisher=Todaysthv.com |accessdate=November 16, 2011}}</ref> He was sentenced to life plus twenty-five years. His imprisonment started at [[Cummins Unit|Cummins Prison]]. By 2004, his sentence was commuted to seventy-five years.<ref name="Arkansas"/>

In June 2010, Leavy died at the age of 70 in the [[List of hospitals in Arkansas|Jefferson Regional Medical Center]] in [[Pine Bluff, Arkansas]],<ref name="Dead">[http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/2010.html Thedeadrockstarsclub.com] - accessed November 16, 2011</ref> having been eligible for parole in eighteen months time.<ref name="Arkansas"/><ref name="Today"/>
